--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...> wrote:
>
> H=
i, it's true that physical problems don't have 8 dimensions, but I was
> th=
inking of the maze problem as an example problem demonstrate the
> techniqu=
e, and that real problems typically have more dimensions.
> 
> As for highe=
r dimensionalities, the problem you've used to test the
method
> has a fair=
ly limited number of locations that can be visited, making the
> novelty me=
mory small. But for larger mazes (and mazes with more
> dimensions), you'll=
 eventually wind up with a lot of novelty memory. 

But is this really true=
?  As I mentioned, we have run novelty search
in these mazes where the beha=
vior is around 400 dimensions, which come
from (x,y) on each timestep.  

T=
hus the space of possible trajectories is astronomical.  Yet even so,
with =
that type of characterization, there was no performance hit (in
experiments=
 not yet published).  What do you think that implies?  Do
you really feel t=
hat one astronomical space is more expensive than
another?  For example, we=
 might have a 3 dimensional maze with a
similar number of timesteps, but th=
at would simply increase the
dimensionality of behavior from 400 to 1200.  =
Those are still both
extremely high dimensional characterizations.  If movi=
ng from 2
dimensions to 400 doesn't hurt, why would moving from 400 to 1200=
?  

I am not making an argument so much as just wondering what you think.
=
 We are still trying to understand what actually makes a problem
harder aft=
er these strange results.

I think it may have to do with complexification,=
 which imposes an
implicit order on the behaviors that are visited.  It ten=
ds to be that
in the real world the behavior we would want is somehow meani=
ngful,
which means it probably takes less neurons than crazy behaviors like=

"go to the left dead-end, turn around, zig-zag until you go to the
right d=
ead-end, then run in circles 13 times and then go to the goal."
 I mean, if=
 that were something you were waiting for, it may take a
very long time to =
come up.

But real world problems seem to require somehow rational, regular=

solutions.  Going through a maze involves at least some general
*princples=
*, as does e.g. walking, or winning a game.

In other words, if the goal is=
 a rational behavior, the neural
networks never become even close to big en=
ough to encompass all
possible behaviors (because they encounter the soluti=
on at a
complexity level well before they get that big) and therefore the
s=
pace of behaviors that might be compared is astronomically smaller
than the=
 space of all possible behaviors.


> The
> main problem with this is that =
each solution is tested against the
entire
> novelty memory and the populat=
ion, which brings you towards O(n^2) which
> isn't good, unless you use som=
e kind of spacial partitioning (which
> requires domain knowledge)/hashing =
method (which doesn't require domain
> knowledge, but is potentially less e=
fficient), that could bring you down
> to O(n*ln(n)). A vast improvement, b=
ut slow compared to what we're
used to
> in GA which typically is O(N). 
> =


However, we are talking about comparing already-characterized
behaviors, =
so the "n" in O(n^2) is not the same "N" that is in the
O(N) for number of =
evaluations.  Comparing two strings is not as
expensive as evaluating an in=
dividual.  Still, there is clearly an
issue in the long run with massive ar=
chives becoming intractable to
compare with.  We do have some results that =
suggest it is possible to
compress archives substantially, also with little=
 loss of performance.
 However, these results are preliminary.  Compressing=
 the archive is
an interesting issue.

> Your solution to problem 2 is inde=
ed elegant, I hadn't thought of that. 
> 
> Lastly, I'm indeed looking forw=
ard to be proved wrong, it would be very
> interesting to see the novelty m=
ethod used on another problem domain. I
> realize the maze problem is very =
graphic, understandable and easy to
> implement, but the novelty method has=
 a strength that the fitness method
> cannot compete with at all; problems =
that have no fitness function
at all
> can still be solved. That's interest=
ing to me. Problems that are either
> solved or not solved but have no grad=
ient between solved and not solved
> can't be sovled with regular GA, but t=
hey can with the novelty search
> method. If such a problem could be found,=
 then that would be very
> interesting indeed. 
> 

I appreciate where you'=
re coming from.  Skepticism is certainly
appropriate and healthy, which is =
why your insights have been very
helpful.  Any other thoughts you have are =
certainly welcome.

ken
